talking about hands in the real world in the lab you can select the objects you're interacting with you can protect
your robot and you can fix it when it's broken all those things are not true anymore when you're in an unstructured
environment and if we want our robots to do dexterous manipulation we need our hands to be resilient because they're
extended from our body and in fact their job is to hit the world right their job
is to contact the world and so you imagine they're going to be stressed very easily with lots of very high contact forces okay
so first I'm going to start with the human hand because people have been inspired by the human hand for centuries
and in this system we have a lot of moving parts we've got input commands that result in some behavior some motion
are forces that behavior results in information gathering so tactile sensing
from our skin and then that combination of behavior and sensing leads to haptic
understanding of the environment and all of these are really important areas in robotic control design understanding of
manipulation my interest has always been in the system design this is how many
fingers do you have do you have a squishy skin what sorts of sensors have you included and this is a system design
question that will influence all of these areas of control and understanding and so I created the embodied dexterity
group and so that's like embodied intelligence is sort of the what what capabilities does the body have
naturally to be well matched with what you want to do and obviously dexterous manipulation so one thing that we can
learn from looking at the human system is that under actuation might be a good way to go when we're designing hands
that are able to do many different tasks so here is a pretty famous study and there's been
you know extensions of this work since then but what they did is they looked at the way that people use their hands the
different sorts of grips that they perform and then they did a principal component analysis and looked at the
first couple few principal components and found that they're actually really good at describing a vast majority of
the grasps that people use so that indicates that maybe just a very small number of actuators is enough to perform
a wide variety of grasps and that's with a device that has many many degrees of freedom so under actuation is a useful
tool of course people have known this for a long time whether intuitively or
explicitly this is a patent from 1919 I've been presenting this all year because it's exactly a century ago so
it's a lot of fun and this is known as like the first hand patent and it's
under actuated which is kind of cool so here's the profile and here's the top
down view here's a profile of one finger we've got three joints and we've got a
single spring going through it and a single tendon so when we pull that tendon it curls up like this so that's
one actuator and three joints and then when we go one abstraction layer higher we've got four fingers and they are all
being actuated by a single tendon and it shares loads between them's with this like pulley device so if one finger
moves back the others will move forward and this is I think a pretty clever mechanism so people have been pretty
good at thinking about this for a long time but of course there are a lot of
new under actuated hands and this is a slide courtesy of Mark this is a really
nice way of describing sort of the variety of under actuated hands that we see so we've got some that are extremely
precise maybe it's a very low degree of under actuation and then we have some that are really really compliant and
flexible really good at conforming to really odd shapes and so this is still
an active area of research and in part it's because today we have miniaturization we have access to new
electronics that's something we didn't have a century ago we have computing ability that can influence how we come

so the B is really I think summarized pretty well the the active areas of research that are still ongoing and that
do very much influence our creation of under actuated designs okay so those
designs while while probably intended for outside the lab they are largely
being tested inside a laboratory environment so what I'm really interested is what happens when we start
to apply these in the field there are extra challenges that we need to overcome and compliance is really

actuated hand you can control the degrees of freedom to either have a certain motion or force but that's not

in summary we're very sensitive to these elements and while we need to select

Springs down here and this is the transmission that shares loads between the fingers so let's think about what

way they all have to change the length the same amount of length so you're creating a sort of a positional

infinitely soft you go to the other side of the spectrum and now all of the tendon tensions have to be that the same
that's a force constraint so by toggling by changing this one parameter the
stiffness of load sharing you go from a position constraint to a force constraint so what do we want this to be
though what does this mean for grasping well here's an example we've got a tube and we're pulling it out of the hand and
you can see that this is the there's only one finger that's resisting the pullout and we want to make sure that
this finger can hold on as hard as it possibly can and so we want this to be a stiff transmission because if we're
going to open this finger we want to have to open all the fingers we want this to be really hard to do and you can
see that in this plot the stiff transmission and holds on much better than the softest
transmission in blue and it's not exactly three times but you're getting approximately that order of scaling so
stiffer is better in this case holding on to less a structures and tools there
are of course counter examples though so here I like this one because it's I think pretty obvious so you've got this
water goblet and it has this thin feature here a stem you want the fingers
to curl and sort of interlock with that geometry in order to resist the pull out
forces in this direction and so in this case we see that the soft transmission in blue is stronger than the stiff
transmission in pink so just because your your tendons are stiff doesn't actually mean that your hand is
necessarily in its strongest configuration okay so I'm not going to go into this but empirically given a
very small set of objects I observed that there's this trend where often we
want either to have the very softest or the very stiffest transmission possible
in these cases you can see that the intermediate stiffness in green pretty
much gives intermediate performance a lot of the time so this is not something I've proven probably has a lot to do
with the friction and interesting things going on in the hand so I do think this is an area for potential future research
to see if this is true over a larger set of objects but given this assumption we
decided to come up with a mechanism that did both the softest and the stiffest so we use these torsional Springs as a

again if your if you didn't quite catch that and you're interested the paper does talk about it and when we were

actually blunt teeth work really well as long as you're able to interlock with that surface you don't want to be too
sharp because you'll actually induce early fracture so we went with this very
simple 3d printed rotational spine design because we're doing a post
pinching we have these sets that interlock with the surface so we can grip on to it
we sort of do a centering behavior and then as we swim forward our spines open
up and interlock with this surface so we're sort of latching in this one directional way so once we grip on in
this way once we pull backwards we're not going to come off now the choice to
use rotational spines does have some consequences one the way the reason why
we wanted to go with this as we said well whenever there's a valley when we have a
spine that's really well engaged with the surface we want that one to squeeze harder so if you have this constraint
and you assume that it can rotate freely you're going to have this relationship
between the angle of your spike and how hard you squeeze so once again the spike
that's down in the valley is going to squeeze harder the problem though is you have this interesting singularity and so
if your angle becomes too steep you now are pushing so hard that you pry your jaws apart and so that was one failure
mode for this gripper it's 3d printed plastic it's very compliant but despite
all of these challenges and the fact that this is very preliminary we're able to hold on to real meza photic coral

um and one other really important element of this is Dawne ability so when

wrists so when they elongate across your wrist your fingers naturally close and
you can actually try this so if you have your hands sort of down your wrist down like this and you flex your wrist up it

when somebody's new to spinal cord injury if they just had one this is an approach that's actually taught as a
strategy a compensatory strategy in order to grasp very small objects the
problem is you're now coupling wrist motion to finger motion and if you have a constraint a motion constraint at your
